bau.description:
"Baús", in Portuguese, are closed spaces where things are kept. "Baús" hold old personal belongings that are no longer used or that need to be well stored, sometimes even secrets or treasures. Often, they are just clutter that one has an attachment to. Family memories.

However, "baú" is also the name of the rear part of trucks, the compartment where goods, moving items, letters, etc. are transported.

This series of photographs began in 2019 when I lived in Rio de Janeiro. On my street, the movement of loading and unloading trucks caught my attention. The feeling of being a stranger to my hometown connected with these impersonal spaces, revealed by their constant inconsistency and the mystery of their interiors.

Thus, the series BAÚ is constructed as a visual investigation of spaces without original belonging — spaces created with the intention of transit, in constant configuration and deconfiguration of their loads, where the intersection between all their places is the empty space.

aboutData.title: About Me
aboutData.description: Julia Kan (b. 1999) is a Brazilian visual artist based in Salvador, Bahia. Her artistic practice is primarily lens-based but is profoundly informed by her background in spatial design, creating a dialogue between photography and scenography. She holds a Bachelor's degree in Performing Arts – Scenography from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ) and is currently a Master's student in the Visual Arts Graduate Program at the Federal University of Bahia (UFBA). Her work is rooted in an investigation of spatiality, perception, and the transformative dialogue between the two-dimensional image and the three-dimensional object. Since 2021, she has worked professionally as a scenographer and production designer for film, theatre, and exhibitions.
